> 1 byte for number of frames (in the case of map files, that should 
always
> be 1)
> 1 byte for x size of frames
> 1 byte for y size of frames
> Then numframes * x * y bytes of actual graphics data (a bunch of 
palette
> indexes since it uses 8-bit color).

Yea, I got the random function to work for placing objects.  However, 
I ran into a problem.

well, I'll give you an example.  I have been testing my random object 
generator using the grid map for scenario 150 - According to the 
built-in scenario editor, dimensions are 1264 by 1248 or 79 frames by 
78 frames.

Extracting the information from the file according to what you said, I 
read the scenario is actually 83 by 83. (I can also verify that by 
noticing that all the objects placed in the new scenario conviently 
fit in that box of 83 by 83.)  [Unless another bug has shown up.  Damn 
it, I have read 6 different scenarios to have that same size 83 by 83 
so I may be dealing with another bug; I keep getting a value of "70" 
for that first byte.]

Also, because that information is 1 byte for x size of frames and y 
size of frames, assumedly, that will need to be mutlipled by some 
factor, probably 16, to determine real x and y max values.
